sections.heading: 4.3.3. Graphene–Metal Nanocomposites
sections.text: Graphene can afford effective protection to metals from chemical or mechanical damages, and contribute to the shielding effectiveness (SE) of EMI shielding device by coating monolayer graphene on transparent metal-meshes.[165] The hierarchical graphene/metal-mesh film has a sheet resistance of 45.0 Ω sq−1 with average transmittance of 90.5% in the vis– NIR region. Both the reflection and absorption of shielding effectiveness have been significantly improved, resulting in superior EMI shielding (SE ≈ 14.1 dB) compared with the metal-mesh-only film. Recently, graphene skin for Cu microlabyrinth (ML) has been reported in which Cu-ML is covered with monolayer graphene grown by CVD method.[166] The Cu-ML with graphene skin shows superior sheet resistivity lower than 5 Ω sq−1 with transmittance of 75%. In addition, graphene and silver nanocomposites hybrid films have been assembled by subpercolating CVD-grown bilayer graphene onto Ag nanocomposites containing nanowires and nanoparticles, achieving a low sheet resistance of 26 Ω sq−1 at ≈80% (550 nm).[167]

sections.heading: 4.4. Graphene Doped with Other Additives
sections.text: Chemical doping is an efficient way to increases the carrier concentration and thus further reduces the resistance of the film. There are two types of doping: p-type and n-type doping. Decreasing the Fermi level of graphene below its Dirac point shows a p-type doping effect. Treating graphene by materials with larger electron positivity leads n-type doping. There are lots of dopants for graphene including HNO3,[87,168] SOCl2,[87,169] Fe(NO3)3,[170] AuCl3,[171–173] FeCl3,[174] Na+,[175] pyrene buanoic acid succidymidyl ester,[176] bis(trifluoromethanesulfonyl) amide,[177] bromine,[178] and APTES.[138]

sections.heading: 4.4.1. Salts and Acids
sections.text:
Doping with salts and acids is an efficient strategy to decrease the sheet resistance of graphene materials without sacrificing the transparency. For instance, p-doping graphene films with AuCl3 or HNO3 decreases the sheet resistance of graphene films as well as increase the work function of OLEDs based on the films.[179] Compared to HNO3, doping a four-layer graphene film with AuCl3 leads to a decreased sheet resistance as low as 30 Ω sq−1. With the four-layer graphene film as anodes, flexible fluorescent and phosphorescent OLEDs have been fabricated, achieving increased luminance, current efficiencies and luminous (power) efficiency.
AuCl3 has been also used as dopants for the modification of trilayer graphene films, which shows a decreased sheet resist-
ance of 150 Ω sq−1 with transmittance above 91% in the visible region. Moreover, doping with AuCl3 increases the performance of OLEDs based on the doped films because of the contribution of doping to the conductivity.[180]
Ferric chloride (FeCl3) has been selected as dopants for graphene films as well. A few-layer graphene (FLG) intercalated with FeCl3 shows enhanced electrical conductivity as well as maintains the high transmittance.[181] After intercalation, the sheet resistance is decreased to 8.8 Ω sq−1 and the transmittance is still higher than 84% in the visible region. Additionally, the doped FLG is highly stable in air due to intercalation.

sections.heading: 4.4.2. Small Molecules
sections.text: Besides salts mentioned above, small molecules such as tetracyanoquinodimethane (TCNQ) has been used as p-dopants to prepare sandwich-like graphene/TCNQ/ graphene films by a layer-by-layer molecular doping process.[182] The sandwiched composite with TCNQ layers displays the increased hole carrier concentration and the decreased sheet resistance. Polymer solar cells with graphene/TCNQ/graphene stacked films show an optimum PCE of ≈2.58%. To improve the hydrophobic surface of graphene films, which always leads to a negative effect on the construction of solution-processed solar cells, pyrene buanoic acid succidymidyl ester has been used to modified the surface of graphene films by noncovalent interaction.[176] In addition, bis-(trifluoromethanesulfonyl)amide has been used to dope graphene films in single layer graphene/n-Si Schottky junction solar cells, improving the PCE of the device from 1.9 to 8.6%, which might be attributed to the reduction of graphene’s sheet resistance by small molecules doping.[177]

sections.heading: 5. Graphene Oxide
sections.text:
Graphene oxide can work as one component of TCFs. However, there are lots of oxygen groups, including hydroxyl, carboxyl and epoxy groups, at the edges of GO as well as in the basal plane. These oxygen groups destroy the conjugated structure of the hexagonal graphene, resulting in low conductivity. Therefore, GO is always used to assist other conductive transparent materials in forming a hybrid material system for TCFs.[183] For instance, GO has worked as soldering materials for AgNW junctions by wrapping around and soldering the AgNW junctions because of its oxygen-containing groups, high Young’s modulus, high flexibility and solution processability.[184] Soldering AgNW networks consequently reduced the inter-nanowire contact resistance, giving the optimum sheet resistance of 14 Ω sq−1 with transmittance of 88% at 550 nm. Fully stretchable OLEDs with the hybrid films as electrodes can survive after 100 stretching cycles between 0 and 40% strain at room temperature. Similarly, by hybriding AgNWs network soldered with the GO flakes, a novel transparent conductive film is fabricated to improve the PCE of graphene/silicon heterojunction solar cells up to 8.68%.[185]
Small Methods 2019, 3, 1800199
© 2018 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim1800199 (27 of 32)
To increase the performance of PEDOT:PSS in OLEDs, GO can work as dopants by spin-coating the dispersion of PEDOT:PSS and GO in water on the substrate.[186] The PEDOT:PSS/GO composite film shows a sheet resistance of 57.1 Ω sq−1 with transmittance of 80% in the visible region. After doping with GO, a better surface morphology (RMS: 1.28 and 1.52 nm), higher work function (5.32 and 5.13 eV) and superior current efficiency (5.71 and 3.67 cd A−1) are achieved compared with the device-based films without doping.
Moreover, in order to improve the optical transmittance, work function and stability of OLEDs without sacrificing conductivity, a graphene oxide/graphene (GO/G) vertical heterostructure has been fabricated by oxidizing the top layer of three-layer graphene films with ozone treatment.[187] This hetero structure electrode shows improved optical transmittance, excellent stability and compatibility with a hole injection layer materials. Using GO/G heterostructure as electrodes, an OLED device exhibits higher maximum current efficiency and power efficiency higher than the device with pristine graphene (ITO) anodes.
Interestingly, GO nanosheets can act as a surfactant to the mediated exfoliation of graphite into a GO-adsorbed graphene complex in the aqueous solution (Figure 29).[188] In this approach, after ground with NaCl, EG powder is dispersed in the suspension of GO in water. The mixture is then subjected to sonication and left to stand for 1 d in sequence. Finally, graphene is separated from the complex and precipitated in the GO supernatant by centrifugation. Moreover, the large lateral size ranging from 5 to 10 µm of graphene can be prepared due to the shielding effect of GO avoiding damage under ultrasonic jets and cavitation formed by the sonication process. The graphene film prepared by the spraycoating of the exfoliated graphene shows a sheet resistance
of 668 Ω sq−1 with transmittance of 80% at 550 nm after annealing at 350 °C for 3 h. A flexible sensor based on the graphene spray-coated PDMS can work under human touch pressure (<10 kPa).

sections.heading: 6. Conclusion
sections.text:
In summary, lots of G-TCFs have been successfully fabricated and applied in optoelectronic devices such as OLEDs, OPVs, and electrochromic devices over the last decade, on the basis of the instinct features of graphene including high conductivity, superior transparency, excellent mechanical flexibility, and remarkable thermal and chemical stability. One of the main and crucial applications of G-TCFs is to work as transparent electrodes for various optoelectronic devices. All the work mentioned above focus on the efforts to decrease the sheet resistance and maintain the transmittance of G-TCFs to meet the requirement of devices. As shown in Figure 30 and Table 4, all these G-TCFs are not perfect, each of which has its own advantages and drawbacks, and needs to be further improved. As discussed above, each of these TCFs as transparent electrodes can meet the requirement of some kind of device because of its own specific properties.
Despite dramatic scientific progress in this field, the practical applications of G-TCFs are still at the early stage. It is still challenging to prepare large-area perfect graphene. Defects, wrinkles and domain boundaries are always introduced in the preparation process and the fabrication process of devices, which will significantly decrease the performance of graphene. Additionally, to meet the increasing demand of optoelectronic devices, G-TCFs with flexibility, stretchability and self-healing should be developed.
Small Methods 2019, 3, 1800199
For real application of G-TCFs, some critical issues should be addressed carefully. Improving the quality of graphene for TCFs fabrication is still one big task, and, for that purpose, more efficient synthetic methods for the mass production of high-quality graphene films should be further optimized and developed. Although CVD methods are favorable for preparing high-quality and large-area graphene, and several production lines have been set up in companies, the efficient transfer techniques of graphene into other substrates and the cost-effective procedures for high-quality graphene film formation are still problems to be solved. Techniques based on the reduction of GO into TCFs seem to be more promising for the industrial-scale and economical production of large-area transparent electrodes, while the conductivity of rGO films needs to be further enhanced. For this purpose, combination or hybridization of graphene with other species should be further studied to capture the advantages as well as to offset the drawbacks of both materials, consequently increasing the performance of G-TCFs. Furthermore, surface modification techniques are essential to make graphene films compatible with active materials in devices. In addition, optimizing the fabrication process of devices and large-scale production strategies for graphene films, like the roll-to-roll method, are necessary to be further developed.
© 2018 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim1800199 (29 of 32)
Although there are still many challenges, graphene-based transparent conductive films have attracted great attention, and will definitely contribute to the development of various optoelectronic devices, particularly for the development of flexible, portable, and smart devices.

The starting material in this route is GO from graphite, which is prepared with the well-known Hummers and Offenman’s method (an oxidation–exfoliation process of graphite).[80] GO sheets are strong hydrophilic because they are heavily decorated by oxygen groups.

metadata.abstractText: DOI: 10.1002/smtd.201800199 devices, particularly those flexible, stretchable, and bendable devices. To address the demand, other alternatives should be explored instead of ITO for TCFs. Graphene is a highly recommended material for TCFs due to its excellent electrical conductivity and optical transmittance in the visible and near-infrared (NIR) region.[3–5,8–29] Moreover, graphene exhibits high flexibility and outstanding chemical stability.[22,30] The single-layer graphene could achieve a potential sheet resistance of 30 Ω sq−1 due to its high electron mobility (200 000 cm2 V−1 s−1).[24] And the optical absorbance of single-layer graphene is as low as ≈2.3%. However, it is still a challenge to produce large-area single-crystalline graphene without any defects and contaminants. Frequently, defects, wrinkles and domain boundaries could be introduced during the preparation process of graphene films. For instance, in the transferring procedure for graphenes grown by chemical vapor deposition (CVD) strategy, wrinkles are always introduced, consequently lowering the carrier mobility. When reducing the graphene oxide (GO) to graphene, some defects are introduced as well. All these drawbacks decrease the conductivity of graphene, which limits its application in devices. As a consequence, it is difficult to achieve the attractive features of perfect graphene in practice. Therefore, many efforts have been made to bridge the gap between theory and practice, through mainly three strategies: improving the quality of graphene, preparing hybrid material system of graphene and other species, and optimizing the structures of the devices. For improving the quality of graphene, controllable synthesis ways have been applied and novel transfer methods have been used. Many emerging materials for ITO replacement, including carbon nanotubes (CNTs), conductive polymers, metal nanowires (NWs), and metallic nanoparticles (NPs), have been selected to hybridize with graphene to combine the properties of other materials and graphene into a single functional electrode. To increase the conductivity and WF of graphene, chemical doping and multilayer graphene film growth have been carried out. By surface modifications, the interface between graphene and active materials in devices has been improved. All these approaches aim to expand its application as transparent electrodes in optoelectronic devices, and have attracted tremendous attention in the field.[31] Most importantly, efficient and economical preparation strategies for industrial The rising demands of optoelectronic devices, such as flexibility, stretchability, and energy efficiency, urgently require alternative transparent conductive films (TCFs) for indium tin oxide. Among all the candidates such as carbon nanomaterials, metal nanomaterials, conductive polymers, and other nanocomposites, graphene is highly promising because of its distinct properties, such as outstanding conductivity, impressive optical transparency, remarkable mechanical flexibility, and chemical/thermal stability. However, the practical application of graphene-based TCFs (G-TCFs) is still challenging due to the difficulty for preparing large-area crystalline graphene with few defects for TCFs. Many efforts have been made to solve these problems, and several kinds of optoelectronic devices have been successfully fabricated with G-TCFs. This review presents the recent development in this area made by the authors and others, including the material systems and synthetic strategies of G-TCFs, as well as their applications as transparent electrodes in optoelectronic devices such as field effect transistors, organic light-emitting diodes, organic solar cells, and other devices. The current major challenges in this area and the potential practical solutions are identified. Graphene
